abstract.p: Dr Richard J Brown letter on July 26 article scores New York City police grilling that wrenched false confession from suspect in attack on Tiffany F Goldberg

block.p: In a July 26 news article, you report that the police wrenched a false confession from a suspect in an assault case after ''20 hours of grilling in a precinct house,'' and that, on the basis of new evidence indicating the suspect was elsewhere at the time of the assault, the Manhattan State Supreme Court ordered his release.

Before she learned that the suspect had been released, the victim, Tiffany F. Goldberg, said, ''It would really compound my suffering to see him handled in merely a punitive way.'' More charity was forthcoming from the victim than from the Police Department, which is charged with, among other things, protecting people.

This practice of ''grilling'' is torturous and a clear violation of human rights. It often leads to false confessions and must be banned.
RICHARD J. BROWN, M.D. New York, July 26, 2000
